articles.headline: Inquiry Started of Financier Who Invested With Madoff
articles.snippet: The New York attorney general has issued subpoenas to determine whether J. Ezra Merkin defrauded universities and charities when he invested their money with Bernard L. Madoff.
articles.abstract: The New York attorney general has issued subpoenas to determine whether J. Ezra Merkin defrauded universities and charities when he invested their money with Bernard L. Madoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. Ezra Merkin, a New York financier, wrote his investors last month that he too was shocked by the news that Bernard L. Madoff’s hedge fund was an elaborate Ponzi scheme.

articles.headline: Bank of America to Receive Additional $20 Billion
articles.snippet: The government agreed to provide a fresh capital injection and absorb as much as $98.2 billion in losses.
articles.abstract: The government agreed to provide a fresh capital injection and absorb as much as $98.2 billion in losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kenneth D. Lewis gambled on bold acquisitions to build Bank of America into the nation’s largest bank.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash, Louise Story and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Senate Releases Second Portion of Bailout Fund
articles.snippet: The 52-42 Senate vote gave Barack Obama a $350 billion war chest, just as Democrats in the House unveiled an $825 billion fiscal recovery plan.
articles.abstract: The 52-42 Senate vote gave Barack Obama a $350 billion war chest, just as Democrats in the House unveiled an $825 billion fiscal recovery plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama’s economic agenda advanced rapidly in Congress on Thursday as the Senate voted to release the second half of the financial industry bailout fund and House Democrats unveiled an $825 billion fiscal recovery plan aimed at putting millions of unemployed Americans back to work.

articles.headline: Health Isn’t a Private Issue When You’re a Legend
articles.snippet: Steve Jobs’s decision to reveal more about his health may not belong entirely to him, not when so much of Apple’s business relies on his personality as chief executive.
articles.abstract: Steve Jobs’s decision to reveal more about his health may not belong entirely to him, not when so much of Apple’s business relies on his personality as chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I am sure all of you saw my letter last week sharing something very personal with the Apple community. Unfortunately, the curiosity over my personal health continues to be a distraction not only for me and my family, but everyone else at Apple as well. In addition, during the past week I have learned that my health-related issues are more complex than I originally thought.”

articles.headline: Credit Markets Showing Some Signs of Revival
articles.snippet: There are limited signs that the credit markets in the U.S. are starting to function, at least for better-qualified borrowers. One of them is the rate on traditional 30-year fixed-rate mortgages.
articles.abstract: There are limited signs that the credit markets in the U.S. are starting to function, at least for better-qualified borrowers. One of them is the rate on traditional 30-year fixed-rate mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is monetary policy finally starting to work?

articles.headline: Yahoo’s New Chief Makes a Decisive First Appearance
articles.snippet: Carol Bartz delivered her first speech since she replaced Jerry Yang as Yahoo’s chief executive, offering the glimpse of a personality very different from Mr. Yang’s.
articles.abstract: Carol Bartz delivered her first speech since she replaced Jerry Yang as Yahoo’s chief executive, offering the glimpse of a personality very different from Mr. Yang’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  When Carol Bartz made her debut in front of analysts, investors and reporters as Yahoo’s new chief executive Tuesday, one thing became immediately apparent: if nothing else, Yahoo’s leadership style had taken a 180-degree turn.

articles.headline: Can Apple Fill the Void?
articles.snippet: Many point to the talent available at Apple as reassurance as Steve Jobs takes a medical leave of absence from the company. But others are looking at the company’s history with worry.
articles.abstract: Many point to the talent available at Apple as reassurance as Steve Jobs takes a medical leave of absence from the company. But others are looking at the company’s history with worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been in the air for some time, but Apple can dodge the question no longer: How important is Steven P. Jobs to its future?

articles.headline: Holder Wants Some Detainees Tried in the U.S.
articles.snippet: Eric H. Holder Jr., the attorney general pick, was also forced to defend his record in the Clinton administration.
articles.abstract: Eric H. Holder Jr., the attorney general pick, was also forced to defend his record in the Clinton administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Eric H. Holder Jr. said Thursday that if confirmed as attorney general under President-elect Barack Obama he would seek to prosecute in American criminal courts some prisoners now held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and would re-examine Bush administration policies he considered legally troubling.

articles.headline: Japan’s Outcasts Still Wait for Acceptance
articles.snippet: The buraku, descendants of a low feudal class, face social discrimination despite decades of affirmative action.
articles.abstract: The buraku, descendants of a low feudal class, face social discrimination despite decades of affirmative action.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYOTO, Japan — For Japan, the crowning of Hiromu Nonaka as its top leader would have been as significant as America’s election of its first black president.

articles.headline: Rescue of Banks Hints at Nationalization
articles.snippet: Losses are so large that the government may have no choice but to take majority stakes in some banks.
articles.abstract: Losses are so large that the government may have no choice but to take majority stakes in some banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last fall, as Federal Reserve and Treasury Department officials rode to the rescue of one financial institution after another, they took great pains to avoid doing anything that smacked of nationalizing banks.

articles.headline: Israeli Cabinet Appears Ready to Declare a Gaza Cease-Fire
articles.snippet: Israel is expected to declare a cease-fire in Gaza and will keep its forces there in the short term while the next stage of an agreement with Egypt is worked out.
articles.abstract: Israel is expected to declare a cease-fire in Gaza and will keep its forces there in the short term while the next stage of an agreement with Egypt is worked out.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s security cabinet is expected to meet Saturday night to declare a cease-fire in Gaza and will keep its forces there in the short term while the next stage of an agreement with Egypt is worked out.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Mark Landler

articles.headline: For Bank of America, the Pressure Mounts Over Merrill Deal
articles.snippet: Bank of America’s chairman came under fire from investors wanting to know why the bank did not notify them of Merrill’s losses in December.
articles.abstract: Bank of America’s chairman came under fire from investors wanting to know why the bank did not notify them of Merrill’s losses in December.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just months ago, Kenneth D. Lewis was the triumphant hero.
